newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish Islamists seethe at army interference.
newsitem.headline: Turkish Islamists seethe at army interference.

text.p: Residents of Istanbul's Fatih district, stronghold of the ruling Islamist Welfare Party, quietly vented their anger on Tuesday at army warnings to end a recent surge of religious activism sweeping Turkey.
"There's no way they can do this. The soldiers should look to military matters and the politicians to politics," said one trader, Abdurrahman, 46.

The generals have ordered Welfare's leader, Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, to crack down on religious radicalism and abandon proposed legislation liberalising the country's laws on religious dress.
Outside the main mosque in Fatih, traders sold combs, scents and mirrors, catering to the many Koran students in the area, some of whose schools the military wants to close.

"The Kafirs (non-believers) say out in the open, 'I'm a communist', or 'I drink wine'. Why can't we be free to live as Moslems, without the army interfering?" said Yunus, 19, a trainee imam (prayer leader).
He sat on a park bench next to a young woman covering her face and dressed head to foot in the black Islamic chador. Like others, Yunus declined to give his surname.
"The government is going well right now, I don't see why they have to interfere with things."
Erbakan leads a coalition with the pro-Western True Path Party. He has embarked on a number of Islamist initiatives in recent weeks that have angered the strictly secularist military.

These include the proposed construction of mosques in secularist strongholds, a lifting of the ban on women wearing of Islamic headscarves in government workplaces and a controversial rapprochement with eastern neighbour Iran.
But such policies go down well with the party faithful who refer to 70-year-old engineer Erbakan affectionately as "Hoca", or Teacher.
"Erbakan has done as well as the most intelligent, most capable man in the world could have done. The government is working very well," said Turgay, a 22-year-old Fatih shopkeeper.

The military has demanded an investigation into the often secretive Islamic brotherhoods, or tarikats, Koran courses and religious-based student hostels which abound in Fatih. They are seen by the army as training grounds for religious extremists.
Islamists counter that such military interference is undemocratic and would not be tolerated in European-style democracies.
"All we want is to be able to dress and behave as we please. If there is any democracy in this country, they shouldn't be telling politicians what to do," said Abdurrahman, the scent seller.
The army previously mounted military coups to end three civilian governments in 1960, 1971 and 1980 and moved tanks through an Ankara Welfare stronghold last month after an anti-secularist rally.
The 1980 coup was immediately preceded by an Islamist rally led by Erbakan in his stronghold of Konya, in central Anatolia.
"I will break the hand that tries to touch my mother's veil. I will go to jail if necessary," Hasan Huseyin Ceylan, a Welfare Party MP was quoted as saying in Sabah newspaper.
Others are not so forthright.
"I got into a lot of trouble after 1980, I don't get involved in politics any more, I don't even talk about politics any more," said Mustafa, as he sold Koranic verses on the streets of Fatih.
"What Allah has written will come true, that's all I know," he said.
